intro: Ipomoea subpedata, commonly known as the red-root morning glory, is a flowering vine native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to deep purple. The plant produces distinctive red or orange roots, which are often used in traditional medicine. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas. Ipomoea subpedata is a member of the Convolvulaceae family, which includes other morning glory species.
